awd_titl_txt: TC: Small: Algorithmics and Security of Lattice Cryptography
awd_abstract_narration: Lattice cryptography is a cutting-edge area of cryptology which has the potential to deliver new and better solutions to many security problems. Lattice algorithms are routinely used to attack and analyze the security of lattice cryptography. However, our current understanding of state-of-the-art lattice algorithms is weak. As a result, the usability of lattice cryptography is severely limited by the lack of high confidence security estimates. Lattice algorithms are investigated, with the goal of providing better understanding of known algorithms, and develop new algorithms as well. Specific goals of the project include: (1) the development of practical variants of the asymptotically fastest known lattice algorithms, (2) the study of analytic models that can be used to predict and explain the behavior of heuristic approaches to lattice problems, and (3) the use of the new models and algorithms to provide concrete security estimates for lattice cryptographic functions. Lattice algorithms are studied using rigorous mathematical methods that provide provable guarantees on the behavior of the algorithms, coupled with extensive practical experimentation to gauge the practical significance of the theoretical results. Computational problems on lattices arise naturally in many areas mathematics and science, from algebraic number theory and communication theory to crystallography and combinatorial optimization. The applicability of the improved lattice algorithms resulting from this project extends beyond cryptography, to reach those other areas as well. Algorithms, experimental data, and instructional material developed in the course of this investigation will be made widely available on the Internet.

por.por_cntn:
The global information infrastructure enabled by computers and the internet has become an essential part of the modern society, from electronic commerce and online banking, to social networking and distributed on-line collaboration. Cryptography is an essential tool to protect this world of information, and it is routinely used (often unknowingly) on a daily basis by most people in any industrialized country. But there are several important challenges faced by cryptography today. On the one hand, most cryptography currently in use is potentially breakable using quantum computers. Even if quantum computers capable of breaking cryptographic functions have not been built yet, if we want today's information (e.g., medical records, etc.) to remain secure for the years to come, it is already time to make cryptography quantum-proof, and efforts to identify and standardize quantum-secure cryptography are already under way. On the other hand, as computers and the internet are used for increasingly complex applications, the type of secure operations one may want to perform using cryptographic techniques has also become correspondingly more complex.

This project investigates a type of mathematical structures, called point lattices, that hold the key to potentially addressing many of the above issues. First, there are several algorithmic problems on point lattices that are not known to be efficiently solvable even using quantum computers, offering a possible basis for the development of a new suite of quantum-resistant cryptogaphic functions. Second, in the last several years lattices have proved to be an extremely versatile tool to develop (at least in theory) a wide range of advanced cryptographic applications, the most famous of which is probably "fully homomorphic encryption" (FHE). This is a method to encrypt messages in such a way that one can still perform computations on them, without decrypting them (in fact, without even knowning the secret decryption key), and obtain the result of the computation again in encrypted form. Point lattices are also interesting mathematical structures, studied for centuries by mathematicians, and find applications in many other areas of science, beyond cryptography, including communication theory and combinatorial optimization. 

This research delivers improved algorithms to solve several important problems that arise in lattice cryptography. For some of these problems, the new algorithms peform orders of magnitude better than previous theoretical solutions, bringing lattice cryptography closer to being usable. Problems for which new algorithms have been developed include

1. The problem of generating  a lattice together with some secret trapdoor information (serving as a secret key, and needed by most advanced cryptographic applications of lattices).
2. The problem of performing computations on encrypted data using a new fully homomorphic encryption scheme.

Improved lattice algorithms are also needed to evaluate the security of lattice cryptography against possible attacks. The project investigates both the theoretical and practical performance of (both old and newly designed) algorithms  used in lattice cryptanalysis. Practical performance is clearly important to get realistic estimates on the cost of breaking cryptographic  functions. But theoretical performance is important too because one is interested in evaluating the cost of attacking lattice problems when cryptographic keys are so large that running the attacks is not feasible in practice. The research demonstrates new lattice algorithms and analysis techniques that can be used to evaluate the security of lattice cryptography with higher precision and confidence than previous methods. This constributes to establishing lattice cryptography as a possible foundation for post-quantum cryptography.
